# Joint Review of Transport Canada’s Aircraft Services

## Solicitation Number and Details

* **Solicitation Number:** 30002732/B
* **Date of Publication:** August 18, 2022
* **Closing Date:** September 6, 2022, 14:00 EDT
* **Amendment Date:** August 25, 2022
* **Expected Contract Dates:** March 20, 2023

## Project Description

The Department of Fisheries and Oceans (DFO) and Canadian Coast Guard (Coast Guard) require consulting services to conduct a comprehensive examination of Transport Canada's (TC) Aircraft Services Directorate (ASD) business lines. The examination aims to identify an ideal organizational construct for delivering TC's aircraft services, optimizing operational effectiveness and fiscal efficiencies while considering benefits to the whole of government.

## Contract Scope

The analysis will encompass five key factors:

* Mandate
* Governance
* Service Performance / Standards
* Funding / Cost Recovery Model
* Asset Renewal / Recapitalization

The scope of work includes evaluating options for providing aviation services, including maintaining the TC ASD status quo or exploring alternative models of service delivery.

## Trade Agreements and Requirements

This procurement is subject to various trade agreements, including:

* Canada-Chile Free Trade Agreement (CCFTA)
* Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP)
* Canada-European Union Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA)
* Canada-Colombia Free Trade Agreement
* Canada-Peru Free Trade Agreement (CPFTA)
* Canada-Panama Free Trade Agreement
* Canada-Korea Free Trade Agreement (CKFTA)
* Canada–Ukraine Free Trade Agreement
* World Trade Organization–Agreement on Government Procurement (WTO-GPA)
* Canadian Free Trade Agreement (CFTA)

## Contract Requirements

* Security requirements: Escort required at DFO sites
* Ownership of intellectual property rights: Canada retains ownership of all intellectual property rights arising from the performance of the work
* Subcontracts or arrangements with third parties require prior written permission from the Contracting Authority
